words.sentence: Wait a moment, while I lock the front door.

words.definition: To cause to be conveyed by an intermediary to a destination.

words.definition: The ability to be enforced, or to be enforced to any useful effect.

words.definition: Partially opened.
words.origin: earlier on char, from Middle English, from on + char turn

words.definition: Any raised flat surface that can be walked on: a balcony; a porch; a raised patio; a flat rooftop.

words.definition: Comfortable.

words.definition: To become or remain attached; to adhere.

words.definition: A grasp or grip.

words.definition: Having a cavity, gap, or space within.

words.definition: Any of various plants of the family Cucurbitaceae grown for food, generally not including the cucumber.

words.origin: Middle English blosme, from Old English blōstm; akin to Old English blōwan

words.definition: A large number of persons gathered together; a throng.

words.sentence: The term "crowd pleaser" is a real backhanded compliment in comedy, being associated with stale, hackneyed, button-pushing routines.

words.definition: One who works on or operates a farm.

words.definition: A mammal of the order Proboscidea, having a trunk, and two large ivory tusks jutting from the upper jaw.
words.origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French olifant, elefant, from L. elephantus, from Greek elephant-, elephas

words.sentence: Young children are naturally curious about the world and everything in it.
words.definition: Tending to ask questions, or to want to explore or investigate; inquisitive; (with a negative connotation) nosy, prying.
words.origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French curios, from Latin curiosus careful, inquisitive, from cura cure

words.definition: Any of several small insectivorous mammals of the subfamily Erinaceinae, native to Eurasia and Africa and naturalized in New Zealand, having dense erectile spines covering the back and sides and characteristically rolling into a ball for protection.
words.origin: Middle English heyghoge, from heyg, hegge + hoge, hogge
words.sentence: Last night, however, I bought a - hedgehog from a wee boy.

words.definition: In scientific usage, any of the animals belonging to the clade Dinosauria, especially those that existed during the Triassic, Jurassic and Cretaceous periods and are now extinct.
words.origin: borrowed from presumed New Latin *dinosaurus, the base of Dinosauria, former reptile taxon, from Greek deinós inspiring dread or awe + -o- + New Latin Sauria, former reptile suborder, from Greek saúros "lizard" + New Latin -ia ,
words.sentence: The name dinosaur comes from the Greek words for monstrous lizard.

words.definition: A set of directions with a list of ingredients for making or preparing something, especially food.
words.sentence: His new approach is definitely a recipe for success.
words.origin: Latin, take, imperative of recipere to take, receive

words.sentence: the brilliant lights along the promenade
words.definition: A finely cut gemstone, especially a diamond, cut in a particular form with numerous facets so as to maximize light return through the top (called "table") of the stone.
words.origin: French brillant, present participle of briller to shine, from Italian brillare

words.sentence: Garbage is collected on Tuesdays; rubbish on Fridays
words.definition: Food waste material of any kind.
words.origin: Middle English, "poultry organs and body parts used for food, poultry refuse," borrowed from Anglo-French *garbage (implied in sergant garbagere "kitchen servant tasked with plucking and cleaning poultry"), of obscure origin

words.sentence: a vacuum of 26 inches of mercury, or 13 pounds per square inch
words.definition: A region of space that contains no matter.
words.origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin (translation of Greek kenón), from neuter of Latin vacuus "empty, unoccupied," from vacāre "to be empty or unoccupied, have space, be free" + -uus, deverbal adjective suffix

words.sentence: It was a surprise to find out I owed twice as much as I thought I did.
words.definition: Something unexpected.
words.origin: Middle English suppryse exaction, seizure, from Anglo-French sousprise, supprise, from feminine of supris, surpris, suspris, past participle of surprendre & susprendre to capture, take by surprise, from sur- & sus-, suz under + prendre to take ,

words.sentence: All the contest judges agreed that Brigitt was absolutely gorgeous.
words.definition: (of a person or place) Very beautiful.
words.origin: Middle English gorgeouse, from Middle French gorgias elegant, perhaps from gorgias wimple, from gorge throat

words.sentence: mermaid smoothie
words.definition: a fabled marine creature with the head and upper body of a woman and the tail of a fish
words.origin: Middle English mermayde, from mere sea (from Old English) + mayde maid

words.definition: Any of a number of winds associated with regions where most rain falls during a particular season.
words.origin: obsolete Dutch monssoen, from Portuguese monção, from Arabic mawsim time, season

words.definition: To continuously attack something with bombs, artillery shells or other missiles or projectiles.
words.origin: earlier, "to fire a large cannon," borrowed from Middle French bombarder, verbal derivative of bombarde

words.sentence: Railway crossings without gates are highly dangerous.
words.definition: Full of danger.
words.origin: see

words.definition: The large, usually yellowish-green or black, pulpy fruit of the avocado tree.
words.origin: modification of Spanish aguacate, from Nahuatl āhuacatl avocado, testicle

words.definition: The second month of the year in the Gregorian calendar.
words.origin: Middle English Februarie, from Old English Februarius, from Latin, from Februa, plural, feast of purification

words.definition: Something possessing structure or form.
(manner) In a special manner; specially.
